author: By Cade Metz and Katie Robertson
title: OpenAI Seeks to Dismiss Parts of The New York Times’s Lawsuit
description: The artificial intelligence start-up argued that its online chatbot, ChatGPT, is not a substitute for a New York Times subscription.
content: OpenAI filed a motion in federal court on Monday that seeks to dismiss some key elements of a lawsuit brought by The New York Times Company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Vibes, Vegetables and Vitriol
description: Attack of the grocery truthers.
content: Whenever I write about falling inflation, I get a lot of comments and mail to the effect that grocery prices have doubled under President Biden and are still soaring. So a few days ago, first on social media and then in a blog post, I pointed out that they haven’t and aren’t. Here’s what the data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics looks like:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: How to Create the Best Kind of Cozy Space: a Room That’s Like a Hug
description: “You can call it different things,” said one designer, but it “all adds up to the same idea: You feel like you want to put your feet up.”
content: On a cold winter day, there’s nothing better than a cozy room that invites you to sink into a comfortable chair and curl up with a fuzzy throw.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Gem in Central Park Reopens
description: The boathouse in the park has a new operator, Korean offal at Ahgassi in Midtown and more restaurant news.
content: It will soon be spring and the Boathouse, which has been a fixture on the edge of the lake in Central Park since 1954 and has had its share of rough sailing, is about to reopen. Legends, the company that runs the food outlets at Yankee Stadium and elsewhere, is now the operator, and the executive chef is Adam Fiscus, working with Dave Pasternack, the consulting chef. Lunch, dinner and Sunday brunch will be served in a setting that’s been refreshed with a color scheme that nods to the plumage of the bluebirds and other avian inhabitants of the park. Visitors can record their sightings in a Boathouse bird registry. The main dining room will feature dishes suggesting traditional Continental style, with oysters Rockefeller, stuffed mushrooms, spaghetti with lobster, fish and chips at lunch, fillet of beef au poivre, prime rib with Yorkshire pudding, and cheesecake. The brunch menu will include crab cakes Benedict. An outdoor cafe area on the north side of the building offers takeout fare with seating for 80; a new indoor cafe area, the Fireside Room has a courtyard. Dockside dining with a separate menu will open later. (Opens Monday)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Criticism of Israel at Berlin Film Festival Stirs Antisemitism Debate
description: The backlash to some winners’ speeches at the festival shows how polarized and fraught Germany’s culture scene has become.
content: When Yuval Abraham and Basel Adra walked onstage at the Berlin International Film Festival on Saturday night, they had come to talk about more than movies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Suhasini Raj and John Yoon
title: Pankaj Udhas, Bollywood Singer and Maestro of the Ghazal, Dies at 72
description: His soulful renditions of ghazals, or traditional love poems, were featured on the soundtracks of hit Bollywood movies and moved generations of Indians.
content: Pankaj Udhas, a singer from India whose soulful renditions of ghazals, or lyric love songs, were a cornerstone of many Bollywood films over his decades-long career, died on Monday in Mumbai. He was 72.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: The Killing at U. of Georgia: What We Know
description: A nursing student’s body was found on Thursday at the University of Georgia in Athens. The authorities called the homicide “a crime of opportunity.”
content: The body of a 22-year-old woman was found in a wooded area at the University of Georgia in Athens on Thursday, sending shock waves through Clarke County, a community about 70 miles east of Atlanta.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robinson Meyer
title: China’s Electric Vehicles Are Going to Hit Detroit Like a Wrecking Ball
description: Do we really want America to become a backwater of bloated, expensive, gas-guzzling cars?
content: It happened very quickly, so fast that you might not have noticed it. Over the past few months, America’s Big Three automakers — Ford, General Motors and Stellantis, the oddly named company that owns Dodge, Chrysler and Jeep — landed in big trouble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Venarchik
title: Virginia Moves Toward Removing Tax Breaks for Confederate Heritage Group
description: The future of tax exemptions for the United Daughters of the Confederacy is likely to depend on whether Gov. Glenn Youngkin signs legislation passed by the Virginia General Assembly.
content: Both chambers of the Virginia General Assembly have passed bills that would eliminate unusual tax exemptions for a prominent Confederate heritage group with long ties to the state, presenting a difficult decision for Gov. Glenn Youngkin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Red Army Faction Fugitive Wanted for Decades Is Arrested in Germany
description: Daniela Klette, who was wanted in connection with the bombing of a prison and violent robberies, was living in plain sight in Berlin, the police say.
content: One of Germany’s most wanted fugitives was arrested on Monday after living in plain sight in Berlin, just miles from the seat of government that the police say she fought to overthrow in the 1990s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Wednesday Briefing: Russia Warned Against NATO Troops in Ukraine
description: Plus, the latest on a possible cease-fire in Gaza.
content: Russia warned yesterday that a ground intervention in Ukraine by any NATO country would lead to a direct clash between the Western military alliance and Russian forces. The response came a day after France’s president, Emmanuel Macron, made a provocative comment about the possibility of allied countries sending in troops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Behind the A.I. Robocall That Impersonated Biden: A Democratic Consultant and a Magician
description: The two men are disputing how the call, which urged New Hampshire Democrats not to vote in the primary, came to be.
content: A Democratic political consultant confirmed that he was behind robocalls last month that used an artificial-intelligence impersonation of President Biden to urge Democrats not to vote in the New Hampshire primary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett
title: What to Know about Lead Exposure in Children
description: Hundreds of children sickened from high levels of lead in applesauce pouches last year put a spotlight on lapses in the food-safety system.
content: A recent outbreak of lead poisoning from cinnamon in applesauce has drawn attention to the toxic effect the heavy metal can have on children. The cinnamon in the applesauce was believed to have been intentionally contaminated, possibly to add to its value as a commodity sold by weight. It had unusually high levels of lead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: ‘Mary Poppins’ Gets New Age Rating in Britain for Racist Language
description: The musical about a nanny with magical powers had been classified for all audiences since 1964, but the British Board of Film Classification has issued new guidance.
content: The rating for “Mary Poppins,” the beloved children’s musical about a nanny with magical powers that was released 60 years ago, has been raised to PG in Britain because of the use of “discriminatory language,” the British Board of Film Classification said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jon Stewart Takes on ‘Something Light’: Israel and Gaza
description: After two “very controversial” appearances behind the “Daily Show” desk, Stewart decided to dial it down a bit for his third.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rita Bullwinkel
title: The Thrill of a Great Steakhouse Isn’t the Food. It’s the Theater.
description: Put on your rhinestones and revel in an old-school fantasy of excess.
content: I love the theater of the steakhouse — the kind that has been open for 50 years and counting, rarely changes its interior design or branding and may or may not adhere to a stodgy dress code (no denim or open-toed shoes!). I mean steakhouses like House of Prime Rib in San Francisco, Hal’s in Atlanta and Bern’s in Tampa, Fla. Inside these classic, old-school steakhouses, I love the way the server asks if you want your salad made “tableside,” if you’d like to see your cut of meat before you order it and if you’d like to tour the kitchen after your dinner. Every great American city has one; really great American cities have at least two or three.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Shogun’ Series Premiere Recap: House of Lords
description: When an English ship pilot lands in feudal 1600s Japan, five lords must decide whether he’s an enemy or a useful pawn in their quest for power.
content: The ghostly Dutch trading vessel Erasmus materializes out of the fog, dwarfing the homes of a small coastal village like a Lovecraft-ian monster emerging from the sea. It may as well be one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Danny Hakim
title: Key Witness Says He Doesn’t Know When Romance Between Trump Prosecutors Began
description: A judge brought the witness back to court as he weighs whether the prosecutors leading the Georgia election case against Donald Trump have a disqualifying conflict of interest.
content: In a potential setback to former President Donald J. Trump and his co-defendants in the Georgia election interference case, a key witness testified on Tuesday that he had no knowledge of when a romantic relationship began between the two prosecutors leading the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Restaurant Review: The Best of Tasting-Menu Culture Meets the Worst
description: At Noksu, dinner is served below the street, a few yards from the subway turnstiles. But the room and the food seem unmoored from any particular place.
content: I can’t remember the last New York restaurant that frustrated me as much as Noksu.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Moskin
title: 30 Chefs Open Up About Tipping, Gen Z Cooks and You the Customer
description: In hours of interviews, we talked with highly accomplished chefs from all over the country about the challenges of running a restaurant today.
content: What do chefs actually think about what it’s like to run a restaurant today? What do they say when they’re being absolutely candid about the job?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser and Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Police Officer Charged With Murdering Two Men in Australia
description: The officer, Beaumont Lamarre-Condon, was charged Friday with killing Jesse Baird, 26, and Luke Davies, 29, who had been missing for more than a week and whose bodies were found on Tuesday.
content: A police officer in Australia has been charged with murdering two men whose bodies were found on Tuesday in a rural area south of Sydney, and the authorities said he had once had a relationship with one of the victims.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Trump Gave Evangelicals Dobbs. They Don’t Seem Satisfied.
description: What the former president says is less important than what key parts of the Republican coalition want.
content: It is very clear that Republicans were caught off guard this month by a decision the Alabama Supreme Court issued that has jeopardized access to in vitro fertilization treatments in the state, because of its conclusion that frozen embryos are “extrauterine children” and that I.V.F. clinics can be held liable for their destruction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Rosenwald
title: Melvin Way, Outsider Artist Who Depicted Inner Mysteries, Dies at 70
description: He struggled with schizophrenia, but he drew praise for the intricate diagrams he drew on scraps of paper while living in New York City homeless shelters.
content: Melvin Way, whose hallucinatory diagrams, composed with ballpoint pens and markers on scraps of paper in New York City homeless shelters, were collected by prominent art museums around the world, died on Feb. 4 in a hospital near his family’s home in Smoaks, S.C., a rural town northwest of Charleston. He was 70.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Isabel Kershner
title: After 4 Months of War, Biden and Netanyahu Are on Different Timetables
description: The divergent goals of President Biden and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu are playing out as negotiators try to reach a hostage deal.
content: President Biden and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel each addressed the future of the battle in Gaza this week, speaking just a day apart but worlds removed from one another in a way that captured the essential tension between the two men after more than four months of fighting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman
title: Macy’s Will Close 150 Stores but Expand Bloomingdale’s and Bluemercury
description: The retailer, under a new chief executive and facing a takeover bid, outlined a three-year strategy to achieve “sustainable, profitable growth.”
content: Macy’s said on Tuesday that it would vastly reshape its strategy and retail footprint, closing about 150 Macy’s stores over the next three years while expanding its upscale Bloomingdale’s and Bluemercury chains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: How California’s Rainy Season Is Shaping Up So Far
description: The state has received 105 percent of its average rainfall for this time of year.
content: With its Mediterranean climate, California receives most of its annual precipitation in just a few months, with the bulk of it falling from December to February.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Broadway Shows
description: What are your favorites? Why?
content: There are 18 shows opening on Broadway in March and April, including a new version of the 1975 musical “The Wiz,”  musical adaptations of “The Notebook” and “The Outsiders,” and plays that star celebrities like Steve Carell and Rachel McAdams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: A Government Shutdown Looms Again, and a Gaza Cease-Fire Could Start Next Week
description: Plus, how lead-tainted apple sauce poisoned hundreds of children.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: Young Voters Say Their Discontent Goes Deeper Than Israel and Gaza
description: “If you’re a Democratic incumbent running for re-election, young voters are an essential part of your coalition,” an independent pollster said, pointing to concerns for Democrats come November.
content: The energy on Michigan college campuses ahead of the 2022 midterms, students said, was electric.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Harris and Keita Morimoto
title: What if Mom’s Not to Blame?
description: In a recent crop of films and television shows, grown men are obsessed with their mothers — even if they’re not the monsters audiences expect them to be.
content: IN ANY DISCUSSION of the enduring cultural madness surrounding the subject of mothers and sons, it would probably be natural to start with Sigmund Freud. But let’s treat as a given all the ways in which he blazed a trail for decades of mother bashing and jump one century forward, so that we can examine the philosophy of a different scholar of male frailty and its relationship to unresolved maternal trauma. “Boy, I love meeting people’s moms,” Ted Lasso says in a 2021 episode of the character’s namesake Apple TV+ series. “It’s like reading an instruction manual as to why they’re nuts.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Food Festival Moves to Brooklyn
description: Order the perfect chicken for coq au vin, try a Croatian amaro and more food news.
content: The Food Network South Beach Wine & Food Festival in Miami just wrapped up this year’s run. Next stop: the New York edition, scheduled for Oct. 17 through 20, but with a big difference. It’s moving its largest events to Brooklyn, to the Brooklyn Army Terminal in Sunset Park. A 450,000-foot sprawl will contain the walk-around Grand Tasting and a host of activities like parties on Pier 4, including a Best of Brooklyn showcase with a capacity for 2,500 attendees. Though Brooklyn will be the focus, the often exclusive Manhattan restaurant events for which the festival is known will continue to be held. “We look forward to welcoming more Brooklyn chefs and partners to this year’s events,” said Lee Brian Schrager, the founder and director. A full schedule and ticket availability will be announced this summer. The festival supports God’s Love We Deliver.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick
title: 2 Men Are Convicted in 2002 Killing of Run-DMC D.J. Jam Master Jay
description: Karl Jordan Jr. and Ronald Washington were convicted of fatally shooting the hip-hop D.J., born Jason Mizell, in his Queens recording studio.
content: Two men were found guilty on Tuesday of killing the D.J. Jason Mizell, known as Jam Master Jay, of Run-DMC, bringing a long-sought conclusion to a case that had confounded investigators and left rap fans grieving for over 20 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Rosen and Maansi Srivastava
title: Corner Offices Are Out; Collaboration Is In. Say Hello to the New Law Firm.
description: The resiliency of remote work has prompted large law firms to rethink their real estate footprint, shedding space even as they bulk up their head count.
content: In January, the law firm Crowell & Moring traded its New York offices in an early 1980s building in Midtown Manhattan for a newly built space on the West Side, with sweeping views of the Hudson River and New York Harbor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber and Tara Siegel Bernard
title: The Costs for I.V.F. Patients After Alabama’s Ruling
description: An Alabama Supreme Court decision has left patients and doctors feeling legally vulnerable, and with many questions. We sought answers from experts.
content: When the Alabama Supreme Court issued a surprising decision this month that led doctors to restrict in vitro fertilization treatments in the state, it raised a host of questions that the court did little to answer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miles Raymer
title: Outfitting Closets When Fewer People Came Out of Them
description: Michael Salem built a retail business by selling to customers like male cross-dressers and transgender women at a time when serving both was more taboo.
content: On a Monday in early February, Michael Salem was contemplating some silicone breast enhancers at a booth inside the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Midtown Manhattan. A section of the venue had recently been taken over by Curve New York, a lingerie trade show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: ‘Saltburn’ Mansion Has Film’s Fans Flocking to the English Countryside
description: A popular video on TikTok takes viewers to the site of Drayton House, where much of the movie was filmed.
content: Drayton House, a privately owned mansion with more than a hundred rooms, has stood in Northamptonshire, England, for close to 700 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Baumgaertner and Ariana Drehsler
title: A Doctor’s Lifelong Quest to Solve One of Pediatric Medicine’s Greatest Mysteries
description: For 40 years, Dr. Jane Burns has been working to find the cause of Kawasaki disease, an illness that can lead to aneurysms and heart attacks. Her work has brought together a most unlikely team.
content: It looked like a scene from the TV crime show “CSI.” Dr. Jane Burns was peering into a multiheaded microscope at the San Diego County medical examiner’s office, scrutinizing autopsy samples from an array of mysterious deaths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Baumgaertner
title: How to Spot Kawasaki Disease in Your Child
description: Cases of this rare, potentially dangerous childhood illness are growing in the U.S. It is often mistaken for scarlet fever, tick-borne diseases or common viruses. Here’s what to look for.
content: Doctors across the United States are seeing a rise in Kawasaki disease, a mysterious condition that primarily affects children under 5. The illness is the most common cause of acquired heart disease in children worldwide but it is often unrecognized or misdiagnosed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Yellen Urges Israel to Restore Economic Ties to West Bank
description: The Treasury secretary said she called on Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to reduce barriers to commerce for Palestinians.
content: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen said on Tuesday that she had personally urged Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to increase commercial engagement with the West Bank, contending that doing so was important for the economic welfare of both Israelis and Palestinians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Thomas
title: The Saga of the Red Couch
description: Jeremy Allen White made the sofa from his Calvin Klein campaign famous, but once upon a time the red velvet couch was part of an ambitious American art project.
content: Toward the end of the Calvin Klein spring 2024 video shot by Mert Alas of the actor Jeremy Allen White stripping down to his skivvies on a Manhattan roof, Mr. White collapses on a red couch for a nap.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Jaap van Zweden to Lead French Orchestra After New York Philharmonic
description: The conductor, whose tenure in New York ends this summer, will begin a five-year term at the Orchestre Philharmonique de Radio France in 2026.
content: The conductor Jaap van Zweden does not leave his position as the New York Philharmonic’s music director until later this summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael H. Keller and Jennifer Valentino-DeVries
title: Instagram and Facebook Subscriptions Get New Scrutiny in Child Safety Suit
description: New Mexico’s attorney general has accused Meta of not protecting children from sexual predators on its platforms. He now wants to know how it polices subscribers to accounts featuring children.
content: The New Mexico attorney general, who last year sued Meta alleging that it did not protect children from sexual predators and had made false claims about its platforms’ safety, announced Monday that his office would examine how the company’s paid-subscription services attract predators.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amal El-Mohtar
title: The War Orphan and the Warmongering Alien
description: New books by Seth Dickinson, Heather Fawcett and Ray Nayler.
content: EXORDIA (Tordotcom, 532 pp., $29.99) is Seth Dickinson’s fourth novel and first work of science fiction, following three installments of the excellent Baru Cormorant fantasy series, and it revisits many of those novels’ themes and structures: empire, war and sacrifice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg and Jillian Weinberger
title: What’s Happening in Michigan Should Scare Democrats
description: Michelle Goldberg on how a new activist campaign supporting a cease-fire in Gaza could hurt Biden in that swing state.
content: Michigan is home to the largest percentage of Arab American voters of any state. On Tuesday, Democratic voters there are heading to the polls for the primary — and the Listen to Michigan movement is encouraging them to vote “uncommitted” rather than for President Biden. The movement’s activists want Biden to call for a cease-fire and end military funding to Israel. The columnist Michelle Goldberg traveled to Dearborn, Mich., and in this audio essay meets with Layla Elabed, Listen to Michigan’s campaign manager, hoping to understand the activists’ aims and what Democrats need to do to win back their support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Family Dollar Is Fined $41.7 Million Over Rodent-Infested Warehouse
description: A federal inspection found living and dead rats at a site in Arkansas in January 2022. Family Dollar pleaded guilty and was assessed the largest food-safety fine to date.
content: The value-store chain Family Dollar was fined $41.7 million, the largest-ever financial criminal penalty in a food safety case, for distributing food, drugs, medical devices and cosmetics from a rat-infested warehouse, the U.S. Justice Department said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Trump and Inflation
description: The former president’s second-term agenda contains few policies that economists believe would reduce the rise in prices.
content: If there is a simple political truth, it’s that voters hate inflation. If there’s another, it’s that they also hate the policies that snuff it out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Ego, Putin or Jets? Reasons for Orban’s Stance on Sweden Perplex Many.
description: The Hungarian leader has given various rationales for stalling Swedish membership in NATO. The real reason may have to do with his own standing and domestic politics.
content: It took 19 months of broken promises and belligerent rhetoric for Hungary to finally ratify Sweden’s entry into NATO.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Democrats Propose N.Y. Congressional Map With Slight Tilt in Their Favor
description: State lawmakers showed restraint in drawing new congressional lines, leaving the districts’ partisan makeup largely intact.
content: A day after rejecting a congressional map proposed by a bipartisan redistricting commission, Democrats in New York unveiled new district lines on Tuesday designed to help the party retake the House majority this fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: The F.T.C. Boosts Biden’s Fight Against Inflation
description: The regulator’s move to block Kroger’s $25 billion bid for Albertsons could win the president points with voters squeezed by rising prices.
content: A paradox at the heart of the U.S. economy is that consumers are feeling squeezed even as growth indicators look strong — and are taking it out on President Biden’s approval ratings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Exxon Raises Questions About Chevron’s $53 Billion Deal for Hess
description: Exxon may try to upend its rival’s megadeal. The prize is a 30 percent stake in the oil-rich fields off the coast of Guyana.
content: America’s two largest energy companies, Exxon Mobil and Chevron, are jousting over a prized new source of oil in the waters off Guyana, in Latin America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rhonda Garelick
title: Yulia Navalnaya, Seen in a New Light
description: To take up her husband’s mantle, Ms. Navalnaya has to forge a powerful public image without him. What will it look like? She has already given us some clues.
content: Yulia Navalnaya, the widow of Aleksei A. Navalny, the Russian opposition leader who died this month in an Arctic prison, has vowed to continue her husband’s work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Netflix Becomes a Broadway Producer With Peter Morgan’s ‘Patriots’
description: The streamer is co-producing a play about Putin’s Russia from the creator of “The Crown” while also developing a screen adaptation.
content: Netflix, the streaming behemoth that has evolved from mailing out DVDs in red envelopes to becoming a hugely important player in the entertainment industry, is embarking on a new adventure: producing on Broadway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: India Zoo Official Gave Revered Names to 2 Lions. He Was Punished.
description: The names, Sita and Akbar, evoking a Hindu goddess and a Muslim emperor, drew outrage from Hindu activists who saw it as blasphemy.
content: The lions look bemused or even bored in photos but not unhappy. Sita and Akbar had been living together for years. Now in a captive-breeding program in India’s eastern state of West Bengal, they are as married as animals can be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Leap Day Wants a Little Respect
description: Those born on Feb. 29 are trying to get some recognition for “a day that doesn’t exist.”
content: The strangest non-holiday of the year is upon us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Preston and Romaissaa Benzizoune
title: Dancing on the Rooftops of New York in a Rediscovered Short Film
description: Louis Johnson, the choreographer of “The Wiz,” could “outdance anyone.” Watch two rarely seen performances here.
content: In 1950, a young Black man traveled north from Washington to New York City. He was stunningly handsome and on the shorter side; his cheekbones sat high in a face hewed for the screen. Against all odds, the 19-year-old Louis Johnson had been accepted into the School of American Ballet; later on, he would describe himself as the “first Black Black” student there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Michigan Tests the Strength of Biden’s Campaign
description: Also, Russia warned against NATO forces in Ukraine. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: Both President Biden and Donald Trump are all but assured to win their respective Michigan primaries today by large margins. But a prominent Democratic protest movement there will offer an important measure of the intraparty division facing Biden’s re-election campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Why a 1934 Concert Is Being Restaged at Juilliard
description: Harry T. Burleigh, who transformed Black spirituals into concert songs, presided over a landmark event that featured the singer who originally played Bess in “Porgy and Bess.”
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll find out about a re-creation of a landmark concert that took place nearly 90 years ago. We’ll also get details on the Manhattan district attorney’s request for a gag order before Donald Trump’s criminal trial begins next month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reggie Ugwu
title: In ‘The Effect,’ Investigating Love and Other Drugs
description: Jamie Lloyd’s revival of Lucy Prebble’s 2012 play, starring Paapa Essiedu and Taylor Russell, heads to the Shed after a celebrated run at the National Theater, in London.
content: The world of experimental medical research might not seem like it has much to say to the world of theater, but Lucy Prebble sees connections. Both require subjects and observers, both take place within a carefully controlled environment and both depend on a certain amount of luck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Graph? | March 6, 2024
description: How is Americans’ love for hamburgers, chicken nuggets and cheese pizza affecting the environment — and specifically groundwater levels?
content: These two graphs were previously published in The New York Times. The original article also includes maps that display the decline in groundwater (or aquifer) levels, in Arkansas because of growing soybeans for chicken feed, and in Idaho, because of growing alfalfa fed to cows which produce milk for cheese.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: A Few Jelly Beans and a World of Disappointment at Willy Wonka Event
description: Families traveled to Glasgow for an event that claimed to channel the magic of “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory.” They got a couple of jelly beans.
content: Families in Scotland were expecting to taste chocolate treats and observe “optical marvels” at a Willy Wonka-themed event in Glasgow this past weekend. Instead, they got a couple of jelly beans, a short walk around a nearly empty warehouse and a visit from police officers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Faye Webster Hates Attention. But Her Songs Keep Getting Bigger.
description: Music that walks the line between indie-rock and country — and her easy access to her emotions — has brought the singer-songwriter a growing fan base.
content: Faye Webster was trying to get out. She had just performed the second of two shows at the Variety Playhouse in Atlanta, swaying in a dark blue gown in front of a 20-piece string orchestra, her hands knitted over her diaphragm. All she wanted next was to go home.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘She Noticed His Stylish Shoes’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: 1965, Calcutta. My 22-year-old mother had rejected several promising suitors who met the requirements of caste and class. “Meet this next one,” her mother begged. “Please. He’s come from Geneva, Switzerland.” En route to a party, Mother quickly dismissed the prospective bridegroom waiting on her family’s sofa. But in her brief, perfumed passage through the living room, she noticed his stylish shoes. And his smile. She agreed to see him again. My father was sweet, gentle. Two weeks after meeting, they married. Then, they flew to Geneva, where they’ve lived more or less happily ever after for 59 years. — Savita Iyer Ahrestani
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully and Patrick McGeehan
title: Can Restoring the Nation’s Highest Business Tax Fix N.J. Transit?
description: Gov. Philip D. Murphy, who let an 11.5 percent tax expire at the end of last year, proposed bringing it back for corporations with $10 million in profit.
content: A year ago, Gov. Philip D. Murphy of New Jersey spoke proudly about his plan to let a corporate business tax expire, framing it as a promise kept in a state striving to compete for entrepreneurs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Why Is Mercury Stubbornly High in Tuna? Researchers Might Have an Answer.
description: Old accumulations of the toxic metal in the deep sea are circulating into shallower waters where the fish feed, new research found.
content: In the 1960s and 1970s, the horrors of mercury poisoning in Japan and elsewhere shocked the world into curbing releases of the toxic metal. Since then, mercury pollution from human activities, like burning coal and mining, has declined in many parts of the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: The Los Angeles Gallery That Found a Market in Great Experimentalists
description: Commonwealth and Council started in a one-bedroom apartment. Now their artists are heading to the Whitney Biennial, Venice Biennale and museums during Frieze.
content: It’s not that Young Chung and Kibum Kim dislike traditional paintings, but as the owners of the gallery Commonwealth and Council in Los Angeles, they prefer artworks that can spin your head sideways. Their roster of 39 artists are known for eccentric practices that sometimes involve welding spacecrafts, transforming into a human disco ball and studying tree bark.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir, Wesley Parnell and Ana Ley
title: Subway Cameras Led to Arrests in D Train Killing, Police Say
description: Investigators say that an early morning argument on a D train last week ended with the fatal shooting of William Alvarez, 45.
content: The police on Monday said footage from a surveillance camera in a subway car helped lead to the arrests of three people in connection with the fatal shooting of a 45-year-old man last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Tuesday Briefing
description: Progress on Gaza cease-fire negotiations.
content: President Biden said yesterday that he believed negotiators were nearing an agreement that would halt Israel’s military operations in Gaza within a week, though Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel had spoken earlier in the day about further military action.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher
title: Want to Feel Bad? Ask TikTok How Old You Look.
description: A new trend has people asking to be roasted by commenters.
content: Cherri Gervais got her first gray hairs as a teenager.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Paul
title: My Impeachment, Too, Was Just a Matter of Time
description: It can happen to any of us.
content: I can’t say my impeachment came as a total surprise. It’s been in the air. Those around me had grumbled about my most flamboyant or frequently recurring failures. My inability to apply rules consistently or to follow through on executive orders. Underenforcement of policies, they said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Developers Who Leveled ‘Britain’s Wonkiest Pub’ Ordered to Rebuild
description: The Crooked House was knocked down last summer after a suspicious fire. Local authorities have now ordered that the owners reconstruct the site brick by brick.
content: The Crooked House, a pub in England’s West Midlands that was demolished last year after a suspicious fire, could soon be rising from the rubble after its owners were ordered to restore the pub to its former lopsided glory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: In Chicago, It’s Summer in February
description: An unseasonably warm winter peaked on Tuesday with melting ice rinks and 70-degree weather. Temperatures will plummet from there, but even so, this winter without winter has left some people rattled.
content: February is usually frigid perfection for the ice rink at Millennium Park in downtown Chicago, a favorite winter stop for tourists and local families that stands in the shadow of the reflective sculpture known as the Bean.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tina Brown
title: Some of the Best Bards Were Women
description: In “Shakespeare’s Sisters,” the Renaissance scholar Ramie Targoff presents an astounding group of Elizabethan women of letters.
content: Judith Shakespeare, Virginia Woolf’s imaginary sister of the Bard, was for years the accepted portrait of the nonexistent writer of Renaissance England. In “A Room of One’s Own,” her seminal feminist essay, Woolf concluded that any glimmer of female creativity in Shakespeare’s time would have been expunged by a pinched life as a breeding machine of children who so often died, disallowed opinions of her own. Had any woman survived these conditions, wrote Woolf, “whatever she had written would have been twisted and deformed, issued from a strained and morbid imagination.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman
title: Levi’s Wants You to Rethink Your Denim Shopping
description: Under a new chief executive, the brand known for jeans is aiming to be a full outfitter, working primarily through its own stores and e-commerce.
content: In the Levi’s store on Market Street in San Francisco, the denim maker’s newly extended collection is on full display. Its mannequins are dressed head to toe in its trademark denim. Black denim overalls are paired with a light-blue long-sleeve denim blouse, complemented by a denim cap. Another dons a denim cross-body bag. A wall of blue jean jackets gives shoppers the option to feel like a hippie, rancher or rock star — depending on which they choose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Berger
title: He Rescued 1.5 Million Yiddish Books. Now He Will Have Time to Read Some.
description: Aaron Lansky spent a lifetime building the Yiddish Book Center, one of the country’s leading Jewish cultural institutions. He’s ready to hand over the reins.
content: Aaron Lansky was a young graduate student in Montreal in the late 1970s when he had an epiphany that changed the course of his life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: What Are Your Favorite Local Businesses?
description: Bookstores, pizza joints, Chinese restaurants, vintage shops, toy stores or anything else. What local spots do you want to celebrate?
content: Local, independent businesses are part of what makes a city or town unique, especially with the proliferation of chain stores and restaurants across the country and around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Jeffrey Gibson Will Bring Sculptures of Ancestral Spirits to Met Facade
description: The Met named its 2025 art commissions, which include Gibson’s facade sculptures and a roof garden installation by the soundsmith Jennie C. Jones.
content: Last summer, Jeffrey Gibson received an honor that most artists wait for their entire lives. Would he represent the United States at the Venice Biennale, the art world’s version of the Olympics? Only a few weeks after accepting, there was another auspicious ring on the telephone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica Sweeney
title: How Do I Get Rid of the ‘Chicken Skin’ on My Arms and Legs?
description: Keratosis pilaris is a common skin condition. It’s also easily treated at home.
content: Q: I have a bunch of small, rough bumps on my arms and legs. What are they, and how can I get rid of them?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman, Patrick Kingsley and Michael Levenson
title: Israelis Broach a Concession in Hostage Talks With Hamas
description: Israel negotiators are reported to be considering the release of high-profile Palestinians convicted of terrorism in exchange for freedom for some of the hostages in Gaza.
content: Israeli negotiators have offered a significant concession in cease-fire talks with Hamas, signaling that they might be open to releasing high-profile Palestinians jailed on terrorism charges in exchange for some Israeli hostages still being held in the Gaza Strip, according to two officials with knowledge of the talks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Senison
title: One Family’s Road to Building a House Despite the Obstacles
description: A family living on the Saint Regis Mohawk Reservation in upstate New York waded through a morass of federal loan programs for their first home. The result was bittersweet.
content: Randa Martin always wanted high ceilings. Her partner, Richard Lebehn, longed for a chef’s kitchen like the ones in all the restaurants where he had worked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: Toyota Recalls Over 600,000 Trucks and SUVs Over Safety Concerns
description: The two recalls, which the vehicle manufacturer announced within a week of each other, were over issues that could increase the risk of a crash.
content: More than 600,000 Toyota pickup trucks and SUVs in the United States were voluntarily recalled over the past week because of different issues that could increase the risk of crashes, the vehicle manufacturer said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Sonne and Constant Méheut
title: Kremlin Warns Against NATO Ground Intervention in Ukraine
description: The warning came in response to comments by President Emmanuel Macron of France, who said “nothing should be ruled out” when asked about the possibility.
content: A provocative comment by President Emmanuel Macron of France about the possibility of putting troops from NATO countries in Ukraine has prompted a warning from the Kremlin and hurried efforts by European leaders to distance themselves from the suggestion.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Weary but Hopeful, Ukrainians Are Unbowed
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, February 27, 2024.
content: “Each missile they shoot at us just fuels our fury.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Sella
title: 2024 Israeli Municipal Elections May Offer a Glimpse of the Political Mood
description: The election will not be a referendum on the performance of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, but more candidates than usual are not advertising connections to his Likud party.
content: Israel held local elections on Tuesday, the first time that voters have gone to the polls since the Hamas-led attacks on Oct. 7 and the war in Gaza reshaped Israeli society and prioritized security on the national agenda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Soltis Anderson
title: I.V.F. Is a Miracle. For Republicans, It Is a Land Mine.
description: I believe children are miraculous blessings and that science is one way miracles are made possible.
content: The grief of infertility can be all-consuming, but also hard to fully grasp for anyone who has blessedly never experienced it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: As Spending Talks Intensify, Johnson’s Bind Grows Tighter
description: Four months into his job as the top leader in the House, Speaker Mike Johnson finds himself the odd man out in increasingly intense talks on how to fund the government and whether to continue aid to Ukraine.
content: At an intense meeting inside the Oval Office on Tuesday, Speaker Mike Johnson was the odd man out.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Shining a Light on Long Covid, a ‘Vicious Affliction’
description: Readers’ personal stories about how devastating it can be. Also: Redeeming cans to make a living; teacher shortages; religion at the border; lounging in bed.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Matthew Goldstein
title: Sam Bankman-Fried Makes His Last Stand
description: Since the disgraced cryptocurrency mogul was convicted of fraud last year, his supporters have maneuvered to secure a lenient sentence and change the public narrative about his case.
content: Since Sam Bankman-Fried was convicted of fraud last year, he has hired a new lawyer known for courtroom showmanship. A group of sympathetic law professors has pushed for a reappraisal of his actions. And his parents have turned for help to former employees of FTX, the collapsed cryptocurrency exchange he founded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Rojas
title: Dad, I Got the Call: Exxon Mobil Wants Me on a Rig
description: To get in on TikTok’s stunt du jour, users are prank calling loved ones to tell them of an exciting (fake) opportunity creating sponsored content on an oil rig. Bafflement generally ensues.
content: For certain social media influencers, brand-sponsored trips are just part of the job. If they’re lucky, they may find themselves admiring the Instagrammably blue waters of the Greek islands, or perhaps the pink sunsets of Bali. But what about endless ocean views from the metal decks of an offshore oil rig?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Lack of Snow Prompts Cancellation of Longest Sled Dog Race in Eastern U.S.
description: The decision to call off the Can-Am Crown International Sled Dog Race for the first time since its inception three decades ago was a matter of safety, organizers said.
content: Jonathan Hayes woke up at 5 a.m. in rural Maine to feed his 20-some dogs Monday morning, and his heart sank when he learned that the sled race they had been training for since the fall was canceled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Burleigh
title: A Secret Garden to Discover Before the Cruise Ships Do
description: Dominica, a remote Caribbean island, enchants with its waterfalls, hot springs and hummingbirds. But a new airport and more tourists could tame its wildness.
content: The hiking trail to Middleham Falls on the Caribbean island of Dominica is all wet leaves, slippery black stones and steps formed by tree roots. It could be a path in Middle-earth, shrouded, shadowy and green, fit for hobbits and fairies. Where sunlight pierced the canopy, rainbows formed in the mist, almost close enough to poke. Here and there, hummingbirds drew nectar from huge blossoms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Otis
title: Mapping New York’s Endangered Languages
description: A new interactive article for The New York Times Magazine captured one group’s efforts to document languages in peril.
content: A few years ago, Alex Carp, a research editor at The New York Times Magazine, learned about the work of the nonprofit Endangered Language Alliance. Founded in Manhattan in 2010 and co-directed by the linguists Ross Perlin and Daniel Kaufman, E.L.A. documents languages spoken in New York City, hundreds of which are endangered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Review: A Soprano Cements Her Stardom in the Met’s New ‘Forza’
description: Lise Davidsen, entering the Italian repertoire at the company, was part of a superb cast as Verdi’s opera returned for the first time since 2006.
content: As dramatic music swirled late Monday evening, the woman trudged a few steps pushing a filthy shopping cart — so hunched and bedraggled that she seemed like an extra, sent onstage to set the scene before the star entered.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Feb. 27, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Feb. 27, 2024.
content: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about the impeachment case against President Biden misrepresented a claim about recordings made of Mr. Biden. An F.B.I. form reporting since-discredited testimony by Alexander Smirnov noted that he claimed to have information on recordings of Mr. Biden involving coerced payments. It is not the case that the allegation contained no mention of tapes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: North Carolina ‘Forever Chemical’ Plant Violates Human Rights, U.N. Panel Says
description: The allegations of human rights violations linked to pollution from the factory broadens a yearslong battle over the site and over the chemicals known as PFAS.
content: The dumping of contaminated wastewater by a chemical plant on the Cape Fear River began more than four decades ago, making the river water unsafe to drink for 100 miles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes
title: After U.S. Strikes, Iran’s Proxies Scale Back Attacks on American Bases
description: Tehran, wary of igniting open warfare with Washington, has told militia groups it backs to curtail assaults on targets such as military installations, Iranian and American officials say.
content: Iran has made a concerted effort to rein in militias in Iraq and Syria after the United States retaliated with a series of airstrikes for the killing of three U.S. Army reservists this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dahlia Scheindlin
title: Myth and Reality in Israel’s Hostage Negotiations
description: It’s been a long time since the Entebbe rescue.
content: Israelis were exhilarated when two hostages held by Hamas in Gaza since Oct. 7 were rescued this month in a daring raid by the Israeli military. It wasn’t just the thrill of seeing the hostages alive in their families’ arms. The rescue reminded many of Israel’s stunning hostage rescue in Entebbe, Uganda, in 1976, when more than 100 hostages from an airplane hijacked by militant Palestinians and Germans were freed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Bruce Newman, Leading Man of Antiques, Dies at 94
description: He oversaw Newel Galleries and its over-the-top treasures that embellished Broadway and Hollywood sets and the living rooms of movie stars and a first lady.
content: Bruce Newman, a New York antiques dealer once known as the Cecil B. DeMille of his profession for his outsized personality and extravagant wares, died on Feb. 9 at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: Army Is Slashing Thousands of Jobs to Focus on Russia and China
description: Recent events suggest that the U.S. military will face challenges in the Middle East for years to come, even as it tries to shift priorities.
content: The U.S. Army is cutting 24,000 positions as the Pentagon continues to shift its priority to countering Chinese and Russian military might after two decades of focusing on the fight against terrorism, according to a new Army document.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William K. Rashbaum and Dana Rubinstein
title: Why the N.Y. Fire Dept. Canceled Its Black History Month Celebration
description: A documentary screening about the city’s first Black fire commissioner was scrapped after his family objected to the film’s exclusion of a Black firefighter group.
content: When the Fire Department sought to commemorate Black History Month this year, a worthy honoree seemed obvious: Robert O. Lowery, New York City’s first Black fire commissioner, who was appointed nearly six decades ago by Mayor John V. Lindsay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Zhang
title: Here’s How the Protest Vote Has Played Out in Past Primaries
description: In past uncompetitive presidential primaries, the typical protest vote has been about 7 percent.
content: While activist groups have urged Democrats in Michigan to cast ballots for “uncommitted” to object to President Biden’s handling of the Israel-Hamas war, the idea of casting a protest vote against a shoo-in nominee is nothing new. In past uncompetitive presidential primaries, the typical protest vote has been about 7 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett and Will Fitzgibbon
title: Lead-Tainted Applesauce Sailed Through Gaps in Food-Safety System
description: Hundreds of American children were poisoned last year. Records show how, time and again, the contamination went unnoticed.
content: Cinnamon-flavored applesauce pouches sold in grocery and dollar stores last year poisoned hundreds of American children with extremely high doses of lead, leaving anxious parents to watch for signs of brain damage, developmental delays and seizures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Esparza
title: The Los Angeles Restaurant That Sold Hollywood on Mexican Food
description: Marlon Brando dropped by once a week. Quentin Tarantino mixed margaritas at the bar. Casa Vega opened nearly 70 years ago in Sherman Oaks, and it’s still a beloved industry hangout.
content: WHEN I WAS growing up in Stockton, Calif., in the 1970s and ’80s, there were only two special-occasion restaurants acceptable to my family. They were both on the south side of the city, in the barrio. My Mexican-born abuelo liked Mi Ranchito, and for my dad it was Arroyo’s Cafe. No matter which one we went to, my order was always the same: rib steak ranchero with rice, refried beans and leaves of undressed iceberg lettuce wilted by soupy salsa. I’d pinch torn pieces of machine-pressed flour tortillas around the slices of steak and mix in all the sides. It was a celebratory meal if there ever was one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Ex-N.Y.U. Official Admits She Stole Public Money to Add Pool at Her Home
description: Cindy Tappe pleaded guilty to grand larceny in connection with her theft of $660,000 in state grant money as part of a broader $3.5 million fraud.
content: A former New York University administrator admitted on Tuesday to spending $80,000 in public money meant for minority- and women-owned businesses on a swimming pool at her Connecticut home as part of a broader $3.5 million fraud she orchestrated, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green and Catie Edmondson
title: G.O.P. Leaders Optimistic on Spending Deal After Meeting With Biden
description: Speaker Mike Johnson and Senator Mitch McConnell were upbeat about efforts to avert a government shutdown. “We are making some real headway,” Mr. McConnell said.
content: Congressional leaders emerged from a meeting with President Biden on Tuesday saying they were optimistic about averting a partial government shutdown at the end of the week, but remained short of a plan to do so before a Friday deadline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Five-Ingredient Peanut Butter Noodles, a Weeknight (or Midnight) Win
description: Eric Kim’s new recipe is a soy-spiked classic in the making.
content: Less is more: These are words to live by in the kitchen, especially midweek between 5 and 8 p.m. There are no trophies for the most time spent toiling on dinner after work, no awards for the most elaborate dishes sailing off your stove on a Tuesday evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: An Emboldened F.T.C. Bolsters Biden’s Efforts to Address Inflation
description: With few unilateral options and little hope of legislation from Congress, the president’s early investment in competition policy could pay a political dividend.
content: An independent federal agency has become one of the most reliable executors of President Biden’s attempts to fight inflation, at a time when the White House has few weapons of its own to quickly bring down stubbornly high prices of consumer staples like groceries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naveen Kumar
title: ‘The Seven Year Disappear’ Review: Looking for Mom in All the Wrong Places
description: A sleekly designed production, starring Cynthia Nixon and Taylor Trensch, aims to skewer the art world but falls flat.
content: The problem with writing a play about absence: How to fill the void? When a performance artist known as Miriam (Cynthia Nixon) vanishes in “The Seven Year Disappear,” a two-hander by Jordan Seavey that opened Monday at the Signature Center, we know only that she is a narcissist who steals the air from any room she enters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: salience
description: This word has appeared in 35 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word salience has appeared in 35 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 8 in “Australia Introduces Workers’ ‘Right to Disconnect’” by Natasha Frost and Isabella Kwai:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Biden Faces ‘Uncommitted’ Vote in Michigan’s Primary. Here’s What to Watch.
description: A protest vote against President Biden’s policies on Israel will show the extent of Democratic divisions, while Donald Trump is favored to win again as Nikki Haley presses on.
content: Follow for live updates on the Michigan primary elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Russian Court Jails Leading Rights Advocate for ‘Discrediting’ Military
description: Oleg Orlov, 70, a co-chairman of Memorial, which shared the 2022 Nobel Peace Prize, was sentenced to two-and-a-half years in prison for speaking out on the Ukraine war.
content: A Moscow court sentenced the co-chairman of Memorial, the Russian rights group that was awarded the 2022 Nobel Peace Prize, to two and a half years in prison on Tuesday for “discrediting” Russia’s military by voicing his opposition to the war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Meet Olivia Rodrigo’s Guts Tour Openers
description: The 21-year-old pop star wears her influences on her sleeve and, in one particular case, books them for her live show.
content: Last Friday night, the pop sensation and verbal vampire slayer Olivia Rodrigo kicked off her Guts World Tour, one of the most anticipated live shows of the year. My colleague Jon Caramanica caught opening night in Palm Desert, Calif., and named it a Critic’s Pick, writing that Rodrigo “brought the perfection and order of musical theater to the pop-punk and piano balladry that her songs toggle between.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: Scientists Are Freaking Out About Ocean Temperatures
description: “It’s like an omen of the future.”
content: From his office at the University of Miami, Brian McNoldy, an expert in hurricane formation, is tracking the latest temperature data from the North Atlantic with a mixture of concern and bewilderment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Review: In ‘Pericles,’ Taking the Cruise of a Lifetime
description: If Fiasco Theater has mixed results in its production of this Shakespearean tragicomedy, it celebrates actors supporting and delighting in one another’s work.
content: “Pericles” is a bit of a mess. Spanning decades and traversing the ancient Mediterranean like some deeply misbegotten Carnival Cruise, this Shakespeare play mingles comedy, tragedy and Christian allegory. There are two assassination plots, two shipwrecks, a brothel, a riddle, a tournament and some very convenient pirates. Deliberately anachronistic, it was described by Ben Jonson, a rival playwright, as a “mouldy tale” and “stale.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: A $30,000 Question: Who Will Get a Free Preschool Seat in New York City?
description: After Mayor Eric Adams made cuts to free preschool for 3-year-olds, families face increased uncertainty — and the prospect of enormous child care bills.
content: In Brooklyn Heights, a couple that wanted to have a second child is reconsidering, anxious over crushing child care expenses and cutbacks to prekindergarten programs.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Remembering Toby Keith and His Complexities
description: A conversation about his loudest (and quieter) moments, and how patriotism has played into country music.
content: The country music superstar Toby Keith, who died this month at 62, was best known for the songs he released in the wake of 9/11 — especially his big, brawny anthems about American power and soldiers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: Surge Pricing for Burgers and Shakes? Wendy’s Will Give It a Whirl.
description: The company plans to introduce dynamic pricing as early as 2025 along with digital menu boards that would reflect price changes, Wendy’s chief executive said during a February earnings call.
content: Maybe you are the type who enjoys biting into a warm, spicy chicken nugget from Wendy’s, and at $5.99 for a 10-piece in Midtown Manhattan, it is a tempting treat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Videos Show Exchange of Gunfire at Houston Megachurch
description: The videos released by the Houston police left open the question of who shot a 7-year-old boy as his mother, armed with an assault-style rifle, exchanged fire with off-duty officers.
content: Just before opening fire with an assault-style rifle in the lobby of a Houston megachurch this month, Genesse Ivonne Moreno walked around the side of her sport utility vehicle and opened a rear passenger door for her 7-year-old son, who got out of the vehicle and followed her into the church.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Review: ‘Oh, Mary!’ Turns an Unhinged Bit Into Real Theater
description: Cole Escola’s play, which imagines Mary Todd Lincoln as a frustrated cabaret singer, surprisingly pulls off stretching a stupid joke to its extremes.
content: “For God’s sake, Mary!” Abraham Lincoln says to his wife in “Oh, Mary!,” Cole Escola’s unhinged historical fantasia that imagines its protagonist as an alcoholic cabaret singer married to a gay guy. “How would it look for the first lady of the United States to be flitting around a stage right now in the ruins of war!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Ryan
title: A Fading Weapon in the H.I.V. Fight: Condoms
description: Some H.I.V. experts worry that the public health focus on prevention medication has accelerated a decline in condom use.
content: Gay and bisexual men are using condoms less than ever, and the decline has been particularly steep among those who are young or Hispanic, according to a new study. The worrisome trend points to an urgent need for better prevention strategies as the nation struggles to beat the H.I.V. epidemic, researchers said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Republican Demands and Divisions Drive Impasse Toward a Shutdown
description: The spending stalemate that has brought the government to the brink of a shutdown is being fueled by G.O.P. demands to add conservative spending mandates opposed by President Biden and Democrats.
content: The spending showdown that has brought the government to the brink of a partial shutdown this week is being fueled by Republicans in Congress, who, after failing in their efforts to slash federal funding, are still insisting on right-wing policy dictates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr and Dolly Faibyshev
title: New York’s School of American Ballet Toasts 90th Anniversary
description: The institution co-founded by George Balanchine celebrated at Lincoln Center on Monday night.
content: When the choreographer George Balanchine co-founded the School of American Ballet in New York City in 1934, the last thing on many people’s minds was dance. The United States was still digging out from the Great Depression and often children dropped out of school to work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden Tries to Turn the Tables on Trump: ‘He’s About as Old as I Am’
description: In his first election-year appearance on a late-night television show, the president joshed with Seth Meyers and poked at former President Donald J. Trump’s own memory lapses.
content: President Biden has come up with a new defense against claims that he is too old to run for another term: At least he knows who his wife is — as opposed to “the other guy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir and Brian Otieno
title: Hunger, Terrorism and the Threat of War: Somalia’s Year of Crises
description: Terrorism, hunger and devastating floods have roiled the Horn of Africa nation. Now, it faces an even bigger challenge: the prospect of war with a neighbor, Ethiopia.
content: A 10-year defense and economic deal with Turkey to protect its seacoast and bolster its naval force. An agreement with the United States to construct five military bases for over $100 million. An enhanced defense cooperation accord with Uganda to boost the fight against the terrorist group Al Shabab.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Jennifer Medina, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Clare Toeniskoetter, Jessica Cheung, Summer Thomad, Sydney Harper, Devon Taylor, Marc Georges, Rachel Quester, Ben Calhoun, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell, Rowan Niemisto and Alyssa Moxley
title: The Voters Willing to Abandon Biden Over Gaza
description: Michigan’s primary election will be a test of Democratic anger over the president’s position on Israel.
content: In the past few weeks, activists in Michigan have begun calling voters in the state, asking them to protest President Biden’s support for the Israeli military campaign in Gaza by not voting for him in the Democratic primary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: The Mystery of White Rural Rage
description: Why do voters prefer politicians who lie rather than help?
content: Will technological progress lead to mass unemployment? People have been asking that question for two centuries, and the actual answer has always ended up being no. Technology eliminates some jobs, but it has always generated enough new jobs to offset these losses, and there’s every reason to believe that it will continue to do so for the foreseeable future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario and Julia Jacobs
title: Sean Combs Accused of Sexual Misconduct by Music Producer
description: Rodney Jones Jr. filed a federal lawsuit on Monday that says the hip-hop mogul made unwanted sexual contact while they worked on an album. A lawyer for Mr. Combs denied the allegations.
content: Sean Combs was sued on Monday by a music producer who accused the hip-hop mogul of making unwanted sexual contact and of forcing him to hire prostitutes and participate in sex acts with them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: Apple Kills Its Electric Car Project
description: The car, which Apple spent billions of dollars researching, had been intended as a rival to Tesla’s E.V.s, which include autonomous driving features.
content: Apple has canceled its plans to release an electric car with self-driving abilities, a secretive product that had been in the works for nearly a decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jameson Montgomery
title: A Designer’s Endlessly Versatile Clothes
description: The London-based Charlie Constantinou creates shape-shifting garments with zippers and detachable legs.
content: Growing up in North London, Charlie Constantinou was a serious piano student who aspired to a career as a composer. But when, as a teenager, he landed a part-time job at a sneaker store, he became enamored with avant-garde streetwear by designers such as Jun Takahashi of Undercover and Nasir Mazhar — the latter of whom, like Constantinou, is a member of the city’s tight-knit Cypriot community. Soon, Constantinou was dreaming up a collection of his own. The creative process, says the Tottenham-based 25-year-old, felt surprisingly familiar: “It’s very much about world building; I get the same feeling from composition.” After studying design at London’s Central Saint Martins, he launched his namesake brand in 2022 when the influential retailers Ssense and H. Lorenzo bought pieces from his master’s degree collection. In the short time since, he’s developed a clearly defined style informed by both ancient history (spiral motifs taken from Cypriot ceramics) and futurism (astronaut-style boots), expressed largely through the use of quilted expandable nylon, a high-tech version of the textile that can stretch and contract to a dramatic degree. He’s drawn to the crinkly look of the fabric, and to the fact that it can accommodate a wide variety of body types: Many of his pieces are one size fits all and, while billed as men’s wear, are meant for people of all genders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: In Ukraine, Russia Is Inching Forward Death by Death
description: Russian forces have an unorthodox view of acceptable levels of military losses, with a willingness to expend troops and equipment to make even small gains on the battlefield.
content: As the Russian military launched its offensive on the eastern Ukrainian city of Avdiivka last fall, Ukrainian troops noticed a change in their tactics as column after column of Russian forces were ravaged by artillery fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan and Amir Hamja
title: The Evil Eye? Not Invited.
description: Fans of the No Nazar party held over the weekend in Brooklyn said the event offers comfort in cultural crossovers.
content: About four years ago, the D.J.s Malinder Tooray, Omar Ahmed and Bianca Maieli hosted a night of music and dancing in Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mari Maeda and Yuji Oboshi
title: The Timeless Ease of Suede
description: A soft, supple hide lends both loafers and lace-ups a laid-back attitude.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: A Single Time
description: Nate Cardin must think he has put one over on us.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Chang
title: High-Stakes Capers Starring Low-Wage Workers
description: Adelle Waldman’s “Help Wanted” and Madeleine Gray’s “Green Dot” skewer the modern workplace.
content: The modern workplace contains and fuels so much of our lives. Who are we when we work? What does our work say about us? It’s no surprise that fiction writers have increasingly turned to the workplace setting, using it as a reflection of society — its power dynamics and cultural shifts — as well as a source of characters’ private ambitions, disillusionments, desires and fears.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Hand
title: Kirsten Bakis’s Long-Awaited Second Novel Is a Busy Gothic Noir
description: Decades after “Lives of the Monster Dogs” comes “King Nyx,” where the wife of a paranormal researcher explores why girls have gone missing from a remote island.
content: Kirsten Bakis has taken her time — 27 years — to produce a follow-up to her acclaimed 1997 debut, “Lives of the Monster Dogs.” Now a classic of weird fiction, the novel depicted a bioengineered canine society struggling to hold its own in modern-day New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Newell-Hanson and Stefan Ruiz
title: A House Where Old Miami Style Meets Old World Eclecticism
description: The 1940s Florida home harks back to a different time — and a different continent.
content: IT CAN BE hard to tell in Miami what’s natural and what isn’t. The sky is often uncannily blue, the vegetation (palms, sea grapes, jacarandas) a startling green. The bright white sand on South Beach is Floridian but trucked in from mines to combat coastal erosion. And the spiny iguanas that look so at home among the tropical shrubs are in fact invasive, descendants of pets imported from South America in the 1960s; sometimes in the winter, they fall frozen from trees, landing on car windshields. Indeed, Miami often seems engaged in a battle against its own wild, swampy environs — a conflict that plays out with growing urgency in the city’s architecture. As temperatures and sea levels rise, the glass-fronted towers along the coast seem increasingly ill suited to their surroundings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilary Achauer and Erik Vance
title: Test Your Exercise I.Q.

title: Hundreds Gather on Beach in Central Gaza as Aid Arrives by Air
description: Large crowds gathered along the coast in Deir al Balah on Monday as Jordan and France airdropped food and other aid supplies, some of which ended up in the sea.
